To understand polarization you need to 
understand the difference between polarized

and unpolarized light. In unpolarized light, 
the electric field oscillates in every 2d plane

along the direction of the light's motion. As 
an example, the red arrow I've drawn on the left

shows light moving to the right. If i place 
a two-dimensional surface along that line,

if the light is unpolarized i know that no 
matter what direction that 2d plane exists in,

there's definitely an oscillation of an electric 
field along that plane. That was a vertical plane.

And if i make a horizontal plane I also know that 
the electric field is oscillating along that plane

because it oscillates along every possible 
2-dimensional plane along the line of the

light's motion. If you look at the bottom, I 
have a view of the light from the front. So you

can see right now I have the electric field 
oscillating up and down and left and right,

but in unpolarized light that oscillation actually 
happens along every possible 2-dimensional plane.

So any line that I choose would have an 
oscillation on it, so that's the definition

of unpolarized light. In unpolarized light, the 
electric field oscillates along every 2D plane

along its axis of motion. In polarized light, 
the electric field oscillates along just one

2-dimensional plane along the direction of the 
light's motion. So this is what polarized light

would look like in comparison to unpolarized

along that up-down line, which we can see is a

That's the difference between unpolarized and 
polarized light. This is the notation that we

use for unpolarized and polarized light. 
You can see that with unpolarized light

it oscillates along every direction whereas with 
polarized light it only oscillates in one plane,

so we use those arrows to show which direction 
the light is oscillating as it moves forward.

Just to put that in writing: the unpolarized 
light notation symbolizes light oscillating

along every possible plane. The view is as 
if the light is moving straight towards us,

and the polarized light notation symbolizes light 
oscillating along only one plane. The angle of the

line shows the angle of the plane. The view is

You're now in a position where you can understand 
polarization, which is the process of changing

unpolarized light into polarized light: changing 
from light with an oscillating electric field

along every 2D plane to only one 2D plane. 
There are two ways we can polarize light. The

first way is to pass it through a polarizer, 
which is a filter that only opens along one

axis and polarizes unpolarized light that 
passes through it along that one axis. So if

this unpolarized light encounters that polarizer, 
the polarizer polarizes the light along that axis.

So that would be what the polarized light would 
look like. It would specifically only oscillate

along the plane opened up by the polarizer. The 
other way to polarize light is to reflect light

off a surface. When unpolarized light is reflected 
off a surface, it leaves the surface as polarized

light only oscillating along the 2D plane parallel 
to the surface itself. So if this unpolarized

light encounters a horizontal surface, the only 
part of the light that will be reflected is the

horizontal polarized component of the light. So it 
would leave the surface as horizontally polarized

light. When light is polarized its intensity is 
divided by 2. One way to think of this is that all

planes of the unpolarized light can be thought 
of as made up of 2 perpendicular components,

like an x-axis and a y-axis, and if you take away 
one of the components you lose 1/2 of the energy

that the wave is carrying, so the oscillations of 
unpolarized light can ultimately be thought of as

having components in 2 perpendicular directions 
whereas polarized light only has components in

one direction, so you basically took away half the 
light, so you're left with half of the intensity.

This is probably the most common thing students 
forget when doing polarization problems.

If polarized light is passed through a second 
filter, its intensity is reduced by a specific

amount relative to the angle between the first and 
second filter. We call the second filter the light

passes through an analyzer. The only part of the 
polarized light that can pass through the analyzer

is the component parallel to the analyzer's 
opening. This means the light leaving the

analyzer will have a smaller amplitude than the 
light entering it, so we'll follow through this

full process: unpolarized light encounters a 
polarizer and is then polarized along that one

axis, and now exists as polarized light when 
it encounters the analyzer. The only component

of it that can pass through the analyzer is the 
component parallel to the opening of the analyzer,

which is smaller than that original polarized 
light. It has a reduced amplitude, so I remember

the amplitude of a wave is the distance from 
the center of a wave to the top of the wave,

and I can see that the distance on this final 
polarized light from the center to the top is less

than that distance in the original unpolarized 
light. So after the light leaves the analyzer,

if there's any angular difference 
between the analyzer and the polarizer,

the light will have a reduced amplitude. Notice 
here that passing unpolarized light through a

polarizer cannot reduce the amplitude of the 
light. No matter the angle, the final amplitude

is the same as the original unpolarized light, so 
the polarizer does not reduce the amplitude. It's

the analyzer that does that later on in the second 
part of polarization. We call the specific angled

lines of the polarizer or analyzer the "axis 
of transmission" or the "transmission axis."

As an example, the difference in angle between

This equation is usually called Malus's Law

and it governs how the intensity of polarized 
light changes when it passes through an analyzer.

Just to put that in writing, the intensity

so that means that 90 minus the angle of

It's just the difference between them,

Moving back into the concepts, sunglasses are 
a common real-world example of polarization.

Sunglasses are meant to reduce glare, so 
the goal is to reduce the intensity of light

passing through as much as possible, and because 
light reflecting off of horizontal surfaces is

polarized horizontally, vertically polarized 
glasses will reduce the intensity the most

because cosine of 90 degrees is zero. Because 
most surfaces that we look at are horizontal,

it makes sense to polarize the glasses vertically 
because when light from the sun is polarized on

the surface it's polarized horizontally, 
so when that horizontal light impacts the

vertically polarized glasses the angle between 
the polarized light and the opening of the glasses

is 90 degrees, and we can use Malus's Law to show 
that when you have cosine of 90 degrees there the

final intensity passing through the sunglasses 
will just be zero watts per meter squared.

You can see this in this video that this actually

the intensity of the sunlight is very drastically

water, and the sunglasses are vertically polarized
